properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Buchan River.

Buchan River:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Buchan River.The Buchan River at Buchan is currently at 2.73 metres and falling, with minor flooding. 

The Buchan River at Buchan is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Sunday. The river level is likely to fall below the minor flood level (2.50 m) overnight Sunday into Monday.


MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT ORBOST

Issued ahead of scheduled update as the Snowy River has fallen below the major flood level earlier this morning.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently falling with moderate flooding. Minor flooding is easing elsewhere throughout the Snowy River catchment.

Since 9:00 am Saturday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Snowy River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Floodwater is toxic and dangerous - it can contain chemicals, sewage, dead animals and other toxic substances. 

Beware of floating debris in flood waters, including trees, hay bales, soil and other floating hazards.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 13/12/2021 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70. 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:
Minor flooding is occurring along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 3.91 metres and falling, with minor flooding. 

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is expected to remain above the minor flood level (2.50 m) during Sunday into Monday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (2.50 m) Tuesday morning.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT ORBOST

Issued ahead of scheduled update as the Snowy River has fallen below the major flood level earlier this morning.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently falling with moderate flooding. Minor flooding is easing elsewhere throughout the Snowy River catchment.Since 9:00 am Saturday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Snowy River catchment. 

No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

Floodwater is toxic and dangerous - it can contain chemicals, sewage, dead animals and other toxic substances. 

Beware of floating debris in flood waters, including trees, hay bales, soil and other floating hazards.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams. 
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides – be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 13/12/2021 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70. 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Warning
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

MODERATE FLOODING OCCURRING AT ORBOST

Issued ahead of scheduled update as the Snowy River has fallen below the major flood level earlier this morning.The Snowy River at Orbost is currently falling with moderate flooding. Minor flooding is easing elsewhere throughout the Snowy River catchment.

Since 9:00 am Saturday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Snowy River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Moderate flooding is occurring along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River downstream of Basin Creek is currently at 4.84 metres and falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River downstream of Basin Crk is expected to remain above the minor flood level (3.50 m) during Sunday into Monday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (3.50 m) Tuesday morning.

The Snowy River at Jarrahmond fell below the moderate flood level (6.20 m) around midday Sunday and is currently falling, with minor flooding. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is likely to fall below the minor flood level (4.10 m) Monday afternoon.

The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 6.82 metres and falling, with moderate flooding. The Snowy River at Orbost is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (6.00 m) overnight Sunday into Monday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (4.20 m) Tuesday morning.
Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property.

Floodwater is toxic and dangerous - it can contain chemicals, sewage, dead animals and other toxic substances. 

Beware of floating debris in flood waters, including trees, hay bales, soil and other floating hazards.
What you should do: 

Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation.

If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.

If you are travelling: 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 

If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for 3-5 days in case you become isolated. 
  • Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground.

You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 

COVID-19 and emergencies  
  • It is important that Victorians are prepared to respond to emergencies in a COVID safe way. 
  • You can leave your home at any time during an emergency or if your safety is at risk. 
  • If you have COVID-19 or you're a close contact, you can leave your home if your health and safety, or the health or safety of someone you live with, is at risk. 
  • Contact the Department of Health using the number you have been provided with when you were contacted as a positive case or close contact, or call the COVID-19 hotline on 1800 675 398. 
  • When leaving your house, wear a face mask and keep 1.5 metres between you and other people. In a life-threatening emergency, call Triple Zero (000). 
  • For more information, call the COVID-19 hotline on 1800 675 398. 
Impacts in your area: 

For detailed information of possible impacts in the area, please see the relevant Local Flood Guides for the Snowy River here.

Possible impacts in the area relevant to river gauge heights could include:

Snowy River height at the Jarrahmond Gauge

  • (4.1M)- B Rd may be flooded west of Bouchers Rd intersection. Other roads may start to see flooding including Birkins Rd, James Rd, Sandy Flat Rd, and other local access roads.

  • (6.2M) - Lynn's and Gilbert's Gulches will have overtopped, beginning to fill the floodplain and isolating properties. Main traffic routes may be affected. 4 buildings may be impacted above floor level in the Bete Bolong / Jarrahmond floodplain.

Snowy River height at the Orbost Gauge

  • (4.1M) - Causes inconvenience. Minor local roads may be closed, and low-level bridges submerged. Inundation may affect farming properties as water backs up drains and irrigation channels, spreading on to paddocks (particularly just north of Icy Creek, Orbost/Newmerella.

  • (4.9M) - 6 Roads may be flooded at this level: Beach Rd, Corringle Rd, Griebenows Rd, Healeys Rd, James Rd and Tabbara Rd, in addition to many more unnamed local/private access roads.

  • (6.0M) - Main traffic routes may be affected including Corringle Rd. Marlo Rd and Old Marlo Rd. Widespread flooding of the farmland north of Marlo toward Orbost East will now occur while a breakout at Gilberts Gulch fills the floodplain from the north (connecting the floods from the Brodribb River and Snowy River).

  • (6.4M) - 2 buildings may be impacted above floor level along Corringle Rd on the lower reach toward The Slips. Alternative routes for access from Marlo to Orbost are required avoiding Tabbara Rd, Marlo Rd and Old Marlo Rd.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 13/12/2021 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Flood information:
  • For river heights check www.bom.gov.au or phone 1300 659 217.
  • For urgent animal welfare issues phone Agriculture Victoria on 136 186 or your local vet.
Emergency contacts: 
  • For life threatening emergencies phone Triple Zero (000).
  • For flood and storm emergency assistance from the SES phone 132 500.
Stay informed: 
  • Go to www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Phone the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on freecall 1800 226 226.
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, phone the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter (#vicfloods) or Facebook.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Mitchell River to Glenaladale.

MINOR FLOODING OCCURRING AT BAIRNSDALE

The Mitchell River at Bairnsdale is falling with minor flooding. Flooding has eased at Glenaladale. 

In the 24 hours to 9:00 am Sunday, no significant rainfall has been recorded across the Mitchell River catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

Mitchell River to Glenaladale:
Minor flooding has eased along the Mitchell River to Glenaladale. The Mitchell River at Glenaladale is currently at 2.80 metres (minor flood level 3.00 m) and falling.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Be aware of dangerous and toxic debris being carried in flood water, including trees, soil, rubbish and dead animals.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 13/12/2021 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70. 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Dandenong South, Hampton Park, Lynbrook.

  • There is a house fire in Bride Avenue Hampton Park.
  •  Smoke May be visible from nearby roads and communities.
  •  Bride Avenue  Hampton Park is closed: 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Health information:

  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Smoke information: Smoke can affect people’s health. For more information visit: https://www.betterhealth.vic.gov.au/campaigns/smoke-and-your-health

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Walkerville, Walkerville North, Walkerville South.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity at Walkerville North Beach. 
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:
  • If you see sharks report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
  • Take extra caution in the area by swimming at patrolled beaches and not surfing or diving in the area.

Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 17/12/2021 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks:
  • www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.
Stay informed:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Call the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for The Honeysuckles.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity at The Honeysuckles near Ninety Mile Beach.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is assisting Wildlife Officers and Park Rangers with the management of the whale carcass.
Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:
  • If you see sharks report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.

Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 13/12/2021 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

For more information on staying safe around sharks:
  • www.vfa.vic.gov.au/shark-smart.
Stay informed:
  • Via www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • Call the VicEmergency Hotline to talk to someone about this warning on 1800 226 226 (freecall).
  • People who are deaf, hard of hearing, or who have a speech/communication impairment can contact VicEmergency Hotline via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.
  • For help with English, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to telephone VicEmergency Hotline. If you know someone who cannot speak English, provide them with this number.
  • Download the VicEmergency app or follow VicEmergency on Twitter or Facebook.

properties.name: Thyra Rd, Moama
properties.webHeadline: A fire has started There is no immediate danger. Stay up to date in case the situation changes

Tomorrow, Mon, 13 Dec 2021 has been declared a day of Total Fire Ban in the Mallee and Wimmera district(s) of Victoria.  No fires can be lit or be allowed to remain alight in the open air from 12:01 AM on Mon, 13 Dec 2021 until 11:59 PM Mon, 13 Dec 2021.
